As global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions continuous increase, the greenhouse effect is becoming an inevitable problem and the conversion of CO2 into carbon-containing clean energy is a hot topic of research. In this paper, a kind of Cd-doped MgAl hydrotalcite composite electrocatalyst (Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO) grown in situ on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The results show that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has excellent performance in CO2RR with multiple active sites, high selectivity and good stability. The structure of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO can facilitate the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalyst and has the relatively best electrochemical performance than the MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs. Its Faraday efficiency (CO FE) is up to 91.5% for the reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO) (-1.1 V vs. RHE), when the partial current density of CO is 3.39 mA·cm−2 and can be maintained for at least 7.5 h (-1.2 V vs. RHE). Therefore, the catalyst may be prospectively used for efficient electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO, and also provides a promising strategy for the design of efficient electrocatalysts in the field of molecular catalysis. Graphical abstract As global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions continuous increase, the greenhouse effect is becoming an inevitable problem and the conversion of CO2 into carbon-containing clean energy is a hot topic of research. In this paper, a kind of Cd-doped MgAl hydrotalcite composite electrocatalyst (Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO) grown in situ on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The results show that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has excellent performance in CO2RR with multiple active sites, high selectivity and good stability. The structure of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO can facilitate the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalyst and has the relatively best electrochemical performance than the MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs. Its Faraday efficiency (CO FE) is up to 91.5% for the reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO) (-1.1 V vs. RHE), when the partial current density of CO is 3.39 mA·cm−2 and can be maintained for at least 7.5 h (-1.2 V vs. RHE). Therefore, the catalyst may be prospectively used for efficient electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO, and also provides a promising strategy for the design of efficient electrocatalysts in the field of molecular catalysis. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon balance Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO CO2RR Electrocatalyst Metal-hydroxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The International Energy Agency (IEA) has released the Global Energy Review: CO2 Emissions 2021 report, which states that global CO2 emissions from the energy sector reach a record high of 36.3 billion tons in 2021, up 6% year-on-year. The consumption of fossil energy is an important cause of CO2 emissions [1], and the problem of resource shortage and the greenhouse effect is becoming increasingly serious, with the greenhouse effect becoming an inevitable problem for human economic and social development [2]. Therefore, the conversion of CO2 into important fuels and chemicals such as carbon monoxide, formic acid, methanol and ethylene [3] by CO2RR not only reduces mankind's dependence on fossil energy sources, but also promises to achieve "carbon peak, carbon neutral" as soon as possible, solving the energy crisis and global environmental pollution problems [4,5]. Compared to photocatalytic [6,7], thermos-catalytic [8] and biochemical methods [9], electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 has remarkable features [10]. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is a typical proton-coupled electron transfer process that can reduce CO2 to carbon-containing organic compounds at ambient temperature and pressure, and has good potential for application [11–13]. Theoretical studies have shown that various intermediates on the catalyst surface are involved in the production of CO [14] and that the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO involves both electrochemical and thermochemical reactions as in Eqs. (1) to (3). Typically, at a current density of 5 mA cm−2, the potential to be applied is between −0.3 and −1 V (vs RHE). In addition, during CO2 reduction, hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) also take place on the cathode surface, as shown in Eqs. (4) and (5) [15]. (1) C O 2 + ( H + + e − ) → * C O O H (2) * C O O H + ( H + + e − ) → * C O + H 2 O (3) * C O + H 2 O → C O ( g ) + H 2 O (4) H + + e − → * H (5) * H + ( H + + e − ) → H 2 HER reduces the Faraday efficiency of the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO. Therefore, it is particularly important to promote reactions (1) to (3) and inhibit reactions (4) and (5). The efficiency of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction is still limited by the activity of the cathode catalyst. Traditional Au/Ag based catalysts [16,17] are highly efficient in catalyzing the reduction of CO2 to CO, but their high cost and low stability have hampered their commercial application. Layered Double Hydroxide (LDH), also known as layered bimetallic hydroxide, has a structure similar to that of hydro-magnesite Mg(OH)2 and consists of MgO6 octahedral shared ribs forming unit layers. These compounds intercalated and assembled into a series of supramolecular materials are called hydrotalcite-like intercalation materials (LDHs). The chemical formula [18,19] can usually be expressed as [M2+ 1-xM3+ x (OH)2] [An−]x/n·zH2O, where M2+ usually refers to the divalent transition metal ions such as Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn 2+,Co2+ etc. that make up the laminate and M3+ usually refers to the trivalent metal ions such as Al3+, Fe3+, Co3+ etc. The presence of trivalent metal ions gives the hydrotalcite laminate a positive charge and An− refers to the interlayer anion which balances the positive charge of the hydrotalcite laminate. Of course, in the synthesis of hydrotalcite there are also water molecules retained between the laminates and therefore carry z crystalline waters [20,21]. LDHs has a relatively strong basicity, and the basicity of the different LDHs largely corresponds to the basicity of the divalent metal hydroxides in their composition. As a layered material, LDHs has the advantages of interlayer anion exchangeability, compositional and structural tunability, but often have disadvantages such as low electrical conductivity, poor stability, easy agglomeration and few active sites when used in electrocatalytic reactions [22]. To improve this drawback, graphene and its derivatives [23] were found to have an ideal crystal structure, ultra-thin thickness of 0.334 nm and excellent mechanical strength, with large specific surface area, high electron transfer capacity, good stability and easily tunable structural and surface properties. Therefore, loading LDHs onto this conducting substrate can improve the conductivity and stability of LDHs and will result in a homogeneous dispersion of LDHs [24–27]. Liu's group explored and found that Ni-AlO(OH)3 hydroxide plays a significant role in facilitating the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO, and loading this hydroxide onto graphene to form a new composite catalyst can greatly enhance the selectivity of CO [28]. Experimental and density functional theory (DFT) results indicate that Cd single-atom catalyst is an effective catalyst for the generation of CO from CO2RR [29,30]. Li's group demonstrate that Cd doping can change the surface geometry and electronic structure of Au nanocarbon and thus the intermediate binding energy, thus greatly improving its CO2RR performance, and that the doped bimetallic clusters have higher CO selectivity and current density [31]. After initially testing and analyzing the electrocatalytic performance of MgAl hydrotalcite (MgAl-LDHs), it can be found that the MgAl-LDHs has some CO2RR activity but inefficient selectivity for CO. It would be possible to improve the selectivity of CO in the reaction by doping with Cd and composite reduced graphene. Because the doping of Cd may enhance the synergy between metal atoms, reduce the overpotential of CO2RR and improve the selectivity of CO; the addition of graphene material may improve the poor conductivity and tendency to agglomerate, increase the specific surface area of the material and reduce the impedance, thus improving its CO2RR performance. Therefore, in this paper, two composite catalysts, Cd-doped MgAl-LDHs (Cd-MgAl-LDHs) and Cd-MgAl-LDHs grown in situ on RGO (Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO), has been designed and synthesized. Their activity for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO has further explored by electrochemical testing. 2 Experimental section Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O), cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate (Cd(NO3)2·4H2O), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), formamide (CH3NO), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), graphene oxide (GO), carbon black, Nafion, anhydrous ethanol (C₂H₆O). All reagents are analytically pure without further purification and the solutions are prepared with deionized water. 2.1 Preparation of materials 2.1.1 Preparation of MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO materials MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis approach. First of all, 0.92 g Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.45 g Al(NO3)3·9H2O were uniformly dissolved in 50 ml deionized water in a beaker mark as A. Similarly, 0.56 g Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, 0.46 g Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.45 g Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 50 ml deionized water in the beaker B and stirred and dispersed evenly on magnetic stirrer. Then, Weighted 0.56 g Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, 0.46 g Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.45 g Al(NO3)3·9H2O and added to the beaker C which contained a sort of mixture solution of 30 ml deionized water and 20 ml formamide with 30 mg GO ultrasonically uniformly. Then 100 ml alkali solution with molar concentration ratio of NaOH to Na2CO3 of 4:1 was prepared. The M2+/M3+ molar ratio was controlled to be 3:1 (Cd2+ / Mg2+ = 1:1). The total concentration of metal cations was 0.16 M and the total concentration of the base solution was 0.32 M. A certain amount of alkali solution rapidly dropped in three beakers respectively under vigorous stirring conditions and the pH of the solution was adjusted to be constant between 8.5 and 9. Next, three kind solution was severally transferred to polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) lined stainless steel autoclaves and placed in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h. After reaction, the autoclaves were cooled to room temperature. Finally, the solid material was separated by filtration, washed several times with deionized water and ethanol successively, dried at 60 °C, and grinded to obtain the final product. The product A was denoted as MgAl-LDHs, product B as Cd-MgAl-LDHs and product C as Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO. The specific preparation process was shown in Fig. 1 . 2.1.2 Electrode preparation Firstly, a mixture solution was prepared including anhydrous ethanol and Nafion solution with a volume ratio of 100:1. Secondly, 5 mg of the prepared catalyst was put into a test tube, next added to 2 mg carbon black. then added 0.5 ml of the configured Nafion ethanol solution and ultrasonically treated 30 min to obtain a uniformly dispersed catalyst suspension. Thirdly, the catalyst suspension was evenly applied to one end of a 1.5 cm×1 cm rectangle of carbon paper using a pipette gun, with the front and back sides being coated with a rectangle of 0.5 cm2 to make a total coating area of 1 cm2. Finally, the coated carbon paper electrode dried in an electric oven at 50 °C and naturally cooled to room temperature. 2.1.3 Characterization of materials X-ray diffractograms were collected on a Japanese Smartlab-SE X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Ka radiation source at 40 kV, 30 mA, step size 0.01, scan rate 8° min−1 and a 2θ angle range of 5° to 80° The full XPS spectrum and the fine spectrum of each element were obtained by means of an ESCALAB Xi+ X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS), USA, as a means of analyzing the surface elemental composition and chemical bonding state of the samples. A Zeiss SIGMA 500 thermal field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to observe the surface micromorphology of the samples. A JEM-2100 high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to obtain a low-resolution image and then a high-resolution image of an area of the sample was taken to analyze the morphology, crystal structure and microstructure of the sample. The specific surface area and porosity distribution of the samples were determined by a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 specific surface area analyzer (BET) and the adsorption and desorption curves were analyzed according to the nitrogen adsorption-desorption method. 2.1.4 Electrochemical testing The CO2RR performance of the samples was investigated using a classical three-electrode system with a Shanghai C&H CHI660E electrochemical workstation. The reference electrode was an Ag/AgCl electrode, the counter electrode was a platinum net electrode and carbon paper coated with catalyst was treated as the working electrode. The electrochemical performance tests were carried out in an H-type two-chamber electrolytic cell separated by a per-fluorinated sulfonate acid ion membrane Nafion 117, the electrolyte solution was 0.1 M KHCO3 solution (pH=6.8) and 20 ml of electrolyte solution was added to both cathode and anode electrolytes. The diagram of electrolytic reaction device was shown in Fig. 2 . A gas flow meter was used to control the CO2 flow rate to 20 ml·min−1. The gas outlet of the reaction cell was connected to a gas chromatograph (PANNA A91 plus, GC, details in the supporting information) and the entire reaction was carried out at room temperature and normal pressure. For comparative analysis, all potentials were reported relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) and the current density obtained at each electrode was normalized by the geometric area of the electrode. An electrolytic reaction occurs at the working electrode (inside the red circle) in Fig. 2, the basic process of which is shown in Fig. S5. At the working electrode surface is a two-electron, two-proton reaction process in which a carbon dioxide molecule is first absorbed at the catalyst surface and then reduced to a *COOH intermediate by a concerted proton electron transfer (CPET) process. The process has two pathways, one in which the initial binding of CO2 to the catalyst involves a proton-coupled electron transfer step to form *COOH, and the other in which the initial binding of CO2 to the catalyst involves an electron transfer step followed by protonation to produce *COOH [32]. Then another H + and an e − attack *COOH, forming H2O and *CO. Finally, *CO is desorbed from the electrode surface to CO and discharged. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and structural analysis 3.1.1 XRD analysis The prepared three catalysts were analyzed for their composition and structure. The XRD spectra of each catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . From the results, the baseline of each spectrum is smooth and the peaks are clearly located and intense, indicating that the samples have a high degree of crystallinity. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the MgAl-LDHs prepared herein show distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ of 11.7°, 23.5°, 35.0°, 39.7°, 47.1°, 60.9° and 62.3°, which correspond to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) crystallographic planes of the Magnesium Aluminum Hydroxide Hydrate, identify with the standard card JCPDS # 35–0964 [33]. This is typical of hydrotalcite crystalline surfaces and no other impurity peaks are present, indicating that the preparation method is capable of yielding MgAl-LDHs of high purity. In Fig. 3 (b), diffraction peaks at 2θ of 11.7° and 23.5° appear are attributed to the (003) and (006) crystal planes of Magnesium Aluminum Hydroxide Hydrate, respectively. This is probably due to the introduction of the Cd element into the Cd-MgAl-LDHs, which partially replaces the Mg atom in the MgAl-LDHs, making the diffraction peak at 11.7° less intense, while the diffraction peak at 23.5° also corresponds to the (012) crystal plane of CdCO3 (JCPDS # 72–1939), resulting in the intensity of the diffraction peak at 23.5° is enhanced. In addition to this, diffraction peaks appear at 2θ of 30.3°, 36.5°, 43.9° and 49.9°, corresponding to the (104), (110), (202) and (116) crystal planes of CdCO3 (JCPDS # 72–1939) respectively. Interestingly, the results in Fig. 3 (c) show that the characteristic peaks of CdCO3 are detected, while the characteristic peaks of MgAl-LDHs are not evident, probably because the amount of MgAl-LDHs formed during the synthesis of the material is low and not detected. 3.1.2 XPS analysis The surface elemental composition of the sample and its valence distribution were analyzed using XPS. According to the full spectrum of Fig. 4 (a), the characteristic peaks at 1303 eV, 531 eV, 405 eV, 284 eV and 74 eV binding energies indicate the presence of Mg, O, Cd, C and Al. As shown in Fig. 4 (b), this is the C 1 s fine spectrum of GO and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO. In GO, the characteristic peaks at 284.80 eV, 286.85 eV and 288.54 eV correspond to CC, CO-C and OC = O bonds, respectively; in Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO, the characteristic peaks at the characteristic peaks at 284.80 eV,285.85 eV and 289.43 eV correspond to CC, CO-C and OC = O bonds, respectively. Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO shows a significant reduction in CO-C bonds compared to GO, indicating that some of the oxygen-containing functional groups on the GO surface disappear at high temperatures during the heat treatment process, reducing the less conductive GO to RGO, thus improving the conductivity of the whole electrode to the benefit of lower over-potentials. Fig. 4 (c) shows the O 1 s fine spectrum of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO, with three sets of characteristic peaks present in the figure at 531.78 eV, 532.86 eV and 533.81 eV, corresponding to the M-O bond (M for metal), the CO-C bond and the OC = O bond, respectively. The XPS spectrum of Cd 3d is shown in Fig. S6 (a), in which a pair of spin-orbit double peaks at 405.99 eV and 412.75 eV correspond to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbitals of Cd2+, respectively. The chemical shifts of the energy band peaks in the XPS patterns are closely related to the charge, electronegativity and oxidation state of the atoms. From Fig. S6 (b) and (c), it can be seen that with the doping of Cd, the binding energy of Al 2p shifts towards the lower field, decreasing by 0.1 eV, while the binding energy of Mg 1 s shifts towards the higher field, increasing by 0.05 eV. Combined with the XRD results, it is due to the partial replacement of Mg by Cd during the synthesis process of the material, resulting in an overall overcharge of M2+. In order to maintain the charge stability of the crystal, Al will absorb the outer electrons of the surrounding M2+, resulting in an increase in the density of the outer electron cloud of Al, which increases the shielding effect on the inner electrons, leading to a decrease in its own electron binding energy and a shift towards the lower field. The Mg atoms are influenced by the Cd and Al atoms, and the density of the outer electron cloud decreases and the electron leaving domain increases, eventually leading to a shift in the binding energy towards the higher field [34,35]. This indicates that the doping of Cd promotes the electron transfer between Mg and Al atoms, enhancing the synergistic interaction between metal atoms and providing more active sites, which is conducive to improving the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalyst, thus improving the catalytic performance. 3.1.3 SEM analysis The surface morphology of the three samples was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fig. 5 (a) shows the SEM images of the experimentally prepared MgAl-LDHs samples, which can be observed as irregular lamellar structure, which is consistent with the hydrotalcite structure, with a wider distribution of larger transverse dimensions between approximately 40 nm and 80 nm and a thinner thickness, indicating good crystallinity of the samples. Compared to the MgAl-LDHs, the transverse dimensions of the Cd-MgAl-LDHs decrease and the thickness increases because the radius of the Cd atom is larger than that of Mg and Al, thus reducing the crystallinity of the samples during the formation of hydrotalcite, as shown in Fig. 5 (b). A muslin-like RGO lamellar structure with many irregular flakes attached to the RGO structure with a wide size distribution can be observed in Fig. 5 (c). A large number of defects and pore structures, as well as some smaller nanoparticles, can also be observed on the surface of the material. These structures will increase the specific surface area of the material, and at the same time facilitate the contact adsorption between CO2 molecules and the material during CO2RR, and directly enhance the catalytic performance of the material. 3.1.4 TEM analysis TEM test was carried out to comprehensively and thoroughly investigate the microscopic morphology of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO composite catalyst. From Fig. 6 (a), the sample has a muslin-like layered structure with irregular flakes (20 nm-40 nm) attached to it, which is consistent with the results obtained from SEM. Fig. 6 (b) is a transmission electron diffraction image of Fig. 6(a), where the diffraction spots form a ring pattern of concentric circles of different radii, reflecting a polycrystalline feature. The pink circles marked in the figure are assigned to the (012), (104), (202) and (116) crystal planes of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO in order from the inside to the outside, which is accord with the results obtained by XRD. The outermost orange ring is assigned to the (116) crystal plane of Magnesium Aluminum Hydroxide Hydrate, verifying the formation of MgAl-LDHs and further confirming the XRD analysis. Fig. S7 (b) shows a high-resolution image of the selected region in Fig. S7 (a). It's IFFT analysis is performed on the selected areas in the pink and orange boxes to obtain high-resolution lattice stripes Fig. S7 (c) and (d), respectively, and combined with the intensity profile images in Fig. S7 (c*) and (d*) to obtain the d-spacing of the crystal planes. The d-spacing 0.291 nm belongs to the (104) crystal plane of CdCO3 and the d-spacing 0.228 nm belongs to the (015) crystal plane of Magnesium Aluminum Hydroxide Hydrate, a result that is consistent with the XRD results. 3.1.5 BET analysis The activity of catalysts is closely related to the internal pore structure of catalytic materials. To explore the effect of morphological structure changes on the specific surface area of catalyst materials further, BET tests were done on three materials, MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO. Fig. 7 (a) shows that the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves of MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs belong to type III, indicating the existence of mesopores on the surface of the materials. Those are with H3-type hysteresis loops in the medium to high specific pressure region, indicating that the pore structure is very irregular and can be considered as slit pores formed by the accumulation of lamellar particles. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curve of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO is of type IV, with a H4-type hysteresis loop in the mid specific pressure region, and the hysteresis loop isotherm has no obvious saturation adsorption plateau, indicating a very irregular pore structure. Fig. 7 (b) shows the pore size distribution of the catalysts. The comparison shows that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has significantly more middle holes than MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs, indicating that the change in morphology enriches the pore structure inside the material and provides more active sites for the catalytic reaction. The BET specific surface area, pore size and pore diameter of the MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO catalysts are listed in Table 1 . In general, the larger the specific surface area of the catalyst, the greater the number of active sites and the greater the catalytic activity. From the data in Table 1, it can be seen that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has the largest specific surface area 167.55 m2g−1, which predicts a potentially high electrocatalytic activity. The pore sizes of the catalysts all lie between 2 nm and 50 nm, which are mesoporous and rich in structure, and are conducive to the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalysts, thereby improving the catalytic performance. 3.2 Electrochemical performance testing and analysis In order to evaluate the electrochemical performance of the three electrocatalysts, MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO, the electrochemical performance of CO2RR was tested and analyzed. The three materials were initially explored by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) and their LSV curves are shown in Fig. 8 (a), which the LSV curves are shown a clear current response. Comparing to the LSV curves of the three electrocatalysts, the current density of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO is found to be significantly higher than that of MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs at the same potential. The current density of MgAl-LDHs is only 8.16 mA cm−2 at −1.6 V vs. RHE and 12.18 mA cm−2 for Cd-MgAl-LDHs, while the current density of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO is up to 15.22 mA cm−2, nearly twice as high as that of MgAl-LDHs. It indicates that the doping of Cd and the addition of RGO enhance the electroconductivity of the material, resulting in Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO exhibiting better electrocatalytic activity. The electrocatalytic reduction experiments of MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO are researched by constant potential electrolysis, the CO2 reduction products are measured and the Faraday efficiency (CO FE) of the target product CO is analyzed. Fig. 8 (b) shows the Faraday efficiency of each catalyst for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO at different voltages. Initial potentials for CO generation are detected at −0.8 V vs. RHE, −0.6 V vs. RHE and −0.6 V vs. RHE for MgAl-LDHs, Cd-MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO electrodes, respectively, indicating that the doping of Cd reduces the overpotential for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. The CO FE of the three samples shows a gradual increase and then decrease with increasing voltage, which means that there is an optimum potential for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to produce CO, and at this potential the material has the maximum CO FE. CO FE maxima of 31.8% (−1.5 V vs. RHE) and 66.5% (−1.2 V vs. RHE) for MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs. Compared to the previous two, Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO shows a substantial increase in selectivity for the production of CO during the reaction. The Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO achieves a CO FE of 91.5% at a voltage of −1.1 V vs. RHE, at which point the partial current density of CO is 3.39 mA·cm−2 (as shown in Fig. 8 (c)). It can be seen that the Cd doping and RGO compositing reduce the overpotential for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction and improves the selectivity of CO. To better illustrate the electrocatalytic activity of the material, cyclic voltammetry (CV) is used to obtain the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) of the material, which is proportional to the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) [36], as shown in Fig. 8 (d). It is calculated that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO had the relatively largest Cdl of 3.78 mF cm−2; Cd-MgAl-LDHs had the second largest Cdl of 2.38 mF cm−2; and MgAl-LDHs had the smallest Cdl of 1.23 mF cm−2. The Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has a relatively large ECSA, corroborating the results of the BET analysis that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO exposes more active sites, increases electrocatalytic activity and exhibits higher conversion efficiency. Impedance tests are carried out on three sample electrodes using the AC impedance technique and a typical electrochemical impedance profile (Nyquist plot of EIS) is shown in Fig. 8 (e). It is well known that the smaller the radius of the arc in the impedance plot, the lower the impedance value representing the electron transport and the faster the rate of electron transfer at the electrode surface. Fig. 9 (e) shows that the order of the capacitive reactance arc radius for the three catalysts is: MgAl-LDHs > Cd-MgAl-LDHs > Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO, indicating that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has the smallest impedance value and the relatively fastest rate of electron transfer at the electrode surface. While the reaction rate at the MgAl-LDHs electrode is slower, which is also consistent with the conclusion that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has the highest catalytic activity in LSV. This shows that the doping of Cd and the compositing of RGO are more beneficial to the electron transfer on the catalyst surface. In the field of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, the long-term stability of the catalyst in the electrolyte is an important indicator for judging its catalytic performance, which is an important prerequisite for the large-scale application of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction technology. Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO is electrolyzed in CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 solution at −1.2 V vs. RHE for 7.5 h at constant voltage as shown in Fig. 8 (F). The current density of the catalyst varied slightly, showing a slow increase with an average current of 5.74 mA·cm−2 and the CO FE basically stabilize at about 84% without any significant decay. It indicates that the Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO composite catalyst has good stability and can be used for long-term experiments on the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO. In addition, the key electrocatalytic performance parameters of the catalysts prepared in this paper were summarized in comparison with other metal compound and RGO composite catalysts (Table S6), and it was found that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO exhibited high CO selectivity in this experiment, and the synthesis method was simple and easy to operate. It was found that the doping of N also increased the active site of the reaction and improved the activity of CO2RR to a certain extent, which provides a way to improve the electrocatalytic performance of this experimental material at a later stage. 4 Conclusion In summary, Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has excellent electrocatalytic performance, it's CO FE reach to 91.5% (−1.1 V vs. RHE). This is mainly due to two factors, one is the partial replacement of Mg by Cd doped during the material synthesis, which broadens the layer spacing of the material, enhances the synergy between metal atoms and promotes the interatomic electron transfer. On the other hand, it is grown in situ on RGO, providing rich internal pore structure and defects with high dispersion, increasing the specific surface area of the material, which is beneficial to improve the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalyst. In constant voltage electrolysis at −1.2 V vs. RHE voltage, the catalyst is able to maintain a stable CO FE stability of around 84% for at least 7.5 h with an average current of 5.74 mA cm−2. Therefore, the present catalyst can be used for efficient electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO, and also provides a promising strategy for the design of efficient electrocatalysts in the field of molecular catalysis. coredata.dc:description: As global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions continuous increase, the greenhouse effect is becoming an inevitable problem and the conversion of CO2 into carbon-containing clean energy is a hot topic of research. In this paper, a kind of Cd-doped MgAl hydrotalcite composite electrocatalyst (Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO) grown in situ on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The results show that Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO has excellent performance in CO2RR with multiple active sites, high selectivity and good stability. The structure of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO can facilitate the adsorption and mass transfer of CO2 on the catalyst and has the relatively best electrochemical performance than the MgAl-LDHs and Cd-MgAl-LDHs. Its Faraday efficiency (CO FE) is up to 91.5% for the reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO) (-1.1 V vs. RHE), when the partial current density of CO is 3.39 mA·cm−2 and can be maintained for at least 7.5 h (-1.2 V vs. RHE). Therefore, the catalyst may be prospectively used for efficient electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO, and also provides a promising strategy for the design of efficient electrocatalysts in the field of molecular catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and performance of Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO in high efficiency electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO
